title: 106_hr583
content: The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of a law enforcement officer. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" includes Assistant United States Attorneys as law enforcement officers in the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System. The Act defines an Assistant United States Attorney as an assistant appointed under section 542 of title 28. The effective date for this Act and its amendments is the first day of the first applicable pay period after a 90-day period from enactment. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. "An incumbent, defined as an Assistant United States Attorney appointed before the Act's effective date, can elect to be treated according to the Act's amendments or as if the Act had never been enacted. The Department of Justice must provide notice to incumbents regarding their election rights within 6 months of the Act's effective date." An election under this subsection must be made before the 90th day after the notice is provided or the incumbent separates from service. No change in retirement coverage will occur before the election is made. Incumbents can elect to be treated according to the Act's amendments or as if the Act had never been enacted. The Act allows for elections to be made regarding retirement coverage, with the Department of Justice required to make additional contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The Act allows for elections for retirement coverage, with the Department of Justice making additional contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. Incumbents as Assistant United States Attorneys before the effective date of their election under the Act may receive retroactive benefits with interest. No individual liability is created for any contribution shortfalls. The Office of Personnel Management will issue necessary regulations, including determining interest on retroactive amounts. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" is defined for this section.
